SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
Hawkes, Evert
Glenside.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

NO. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: Everett Hawker
2. Your address: Glencairn, Sask.
3. Date: March 14, 1952
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Ruthran, Ont.
5. What was your father's name and occupation? David Hawker, Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): June 1, 1882
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Ruthran, Ont.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.). I was 2 years old
9. What were your reasons for coming West? Came with my parents hearing about the great opportunities
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?). I expect they read about it

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   They thought it was a great adventure.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   Family

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   The family came by train all the way. My father came as far as Brandon by train and from there by ox team.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   I don't remember. I was only two years old, most of this information is from my parents talk about it.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   Moose Jaw

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   Caron

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   Eskbank
   Glenside

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
   After I grew up I farmed. I bought land when I was 16 years old, and farmed for 12 years. Then I was in the mercantile trade for 12 years and have farmed since that.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They thought it was a great adventure.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

Family

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Train all the way my father came as far as Brandon by train and from there by ox team.

14. What incidents of the Journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement.)

I don't remember it was only two years old most of this information is from my parents talk about it.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Church hall

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Caron

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Estherville

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

After I came I farmed I bought land when I was 16 years old and farmed for 11 years then I was in the mercantile trade for 11 years and have farmed since then.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   They corresponded quite frequently.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
    Bella Bell in 1904 Jan 6 at Boham

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
    just three or four families

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
    they all came in 1882 7 sisters & 5 brothers

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
    I can remember they had to pick buffalo bones off the land before they could break it. They were so many they sold them for $70 a ton.
    There were lots of Indians with old red river carts looking bones to about the time of the Reil rebellion.
    They transported supplies to the army right past our place.
    There were lots of other things if I could remember them.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
    We used to travel around the country quite a little usually by oxen later we got horses.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, who?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

I can remember this road to Pick Buffalo Boreas. They sold them for $5 per ton. They were lots of Indians with old red river carts. Rocking horses to about the time of the Red Rebellion. They transported supplies to the army right past our place. They were lots of other things if I could. Remember these.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

We used to travel around the country quite a little usually by oxen. Later we got horses.
25. When was the first car used in the community? about 1906 or 7

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   I bought a close car in 1913

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   at first it was more than 20 miles away, later it was closer 3 miles away

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   we traded there for many years, it got to be a little village where you could get most all goods you needed

29. How often did you shop in the early days? about once a month

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   about 1900

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   I think it was about 1900
   the articles usually were things that could not be obtained in our local stores such as wearing apparel the percentage would be very small

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   in 1909 Bell Telephone I think

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   My Father came here with the intention of making it a permanent home
25. When was the first car used in the community? about 1906 or 7

31. When did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogs? (What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what was purchased next year.) Purchases were by mail order and any charges in town.

32. Then did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of starting permanently? Or did you make up your mind at that time to make this decision?

My father came here with the intention of making it a permanent home.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

A few families went back to Ontario about 1889 just couldn't make a go of it, odd ones came back later.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920's? Did many return?

There were quite a number, some came back.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I was on the rural municipal council no. 284 for 10 years from 1939 to 1949.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

My oldest brother was the first man to use Blue Stone for treating wheat for smut in 1891. I was the first one to use a disc plough in our district in 1899.
